div.p: I shall be leaving this on the 1st and hope to be with you on the 15th July, remaining till convenient, till the 18th, a Saturday.

Do not arrange for a meeting between me and William James. My position towards him is far more complicated + difficult than that of intellectual opposition (perhaps you have glanced at the Need Will to Believe paper in the book dedicated to you?). It is this. Many years ago Mr William James, whom I know slightly, attacked me very violently (privately) for having put a person resembling his brother into one of the stories of a volume (quite forgotten) called Vanitas. The attack was exaggerated and unmannerly, and it had the effect that for more than ten years Mr Henry James, an old, kind + dear friend of mine, refused (without having read that story) to meet me. Some years ago we did meet, and are, I trust, good friends again. But I have no wish ever to meet Mr William James, whose fraternal fury not merely cost me a friendship which I greatly prized, but (I being then comparatively young) broke my nerve utterly as a writer of modern stories, filling me with the constant fear of putting in real people -

That is my care. By an odd coincidence, after admiring Wm James’s Psychological work more than everything, and even (this was after that quarrel) writing in favour of the Lange=James theory, I had occasion to fall foul of him in his “Will-to-Believe” capacity; and now I have ready half a volume against Pragmatism as incarnated in him + Schiller - Everyone who knows of our quarrel will imagine that my hostility (I being a woman!) to the “Will to Believe” is due to William James’ having been horrid about that old story of mine. It is not so. But, what between my poor little story in the past, and my articles against Pragmatism in the present + the future, I think a meeting between us would be a mistake.
div.closer: I will write later to Mrs Wells to settle more exactly. Meanwhile my love to her + all thanks to both, Yrs truly V. Paget
